Persephone, Seasonal Adjustment with an Object-oriented Wrapper for RJDemetra

Angelika Meraner, Gregor de Cillia, Alexander Kowarik

2021-02-19

Source: vignettes/persephone-saceWorkshop.Rmd
persephone-saceWorkshop.Rmd

Introduction

The R-package (R Core Team 2019) persephone (Meraner, de Cillia, and Kowarik 2019) was developed and is still under development to enable easy processing of multiple time series during the production of seasonally adjusted estimates. It will be used as a successor of the R package x12 (Kowarik et al. 2014) which is currently used at Statistics Austria.

RJDemetra (Quartier-la-Tente et al. 2019), an R interface to JDemetra+ (https://github.com/jdemetra) is used to perform the seasonal adjustment. Additionally, analytic tools such as interactive plots are developed to support the SA expert. These tools makes it easy to construct personalized dashboards containing selected plots and diagnostics and to produce a Eurostat-Quality-Report. The support of hierarchical time series is of importance in the workflow within an official statistics agency and in the future, diagnostics for the comparison between direct and indirect seasonal adjustment will be included.

Note on the package name: Obviously, Persephone (Wikipedia contributors 2019) is an offspring of Demetra (Demeter) and Zeus and also a vegetation goddess. Therefore, it is a natural choice.

Installation

As the package is not yet on the comprehensive R archive network (CRAN http://cran.r-project.org), the main R package repository, it can be installed from GitHub via the following command:

devtools::install_github("statistikat/persephone")

Optionally and preferably, it can be installed including vignettes (needs prettydoc (Qiu 2019)).

devtools::install_github("statistikat/persephone", build_vignettes = TRUE)

After installation, the package can be loaded into the current R session.

library(persephone)

Constructing Persephone Objects

An object of class persephone can be constructed from only one or multiple time series. These multiple time series can be connected through a certain hierarchy. Depending on whether seasonal adjustment should be performed with X-13-ARIMA-SEATS (Bureau 2019) or with TRAMO-SEATS (Gómez and Maravall 2001), ‘single’ persephone objects are constructed with the functions perX13() or perTramo(). Multiple ‘single’ objects can then be combined with perHts() to build a hierarchical persephone object. Batch objects without a hierarchy can be represented as objects with a flat hierarchy at the moment, but this will be improved in the future.

Persephone objects call the functions of RJDemetra in the background, so for a detailed documentation on the respective X-13 or TRAMO-SEATS methods refer to the R-help of RJDemetra.

Persephone Single Objects

Univariate persephone objects are created with perX13() or perTramo() from univariate time series objects such as the AirPassengers data set. A predefined JDemetra+ model specification has to be provided by the user, in this example we use "RSA3" (Log/level detection = automatic, Outliers detection = automatic, Calendar effects = NA, ARIMA = automatic).

data(AirPassengers, package = "datasets")
obj_x13 <- perX13(AirPassengers, "RSA3")

Now different methods can be called for the persephone object obj_x13. Most prominently, the run() method performs a call to JDemetra+ through RJDemetra to actually run the seasonal adjustment method. The output field gives access to the original output object from RJDemetra. Before the first run, some methods for the object will not work and some fields will be empty since no results are available yet.

obj_x13$run()
obj_x13$output$regarima
## y = regression model + arima (0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1)
## Log-transformation: yes
## Coefficients:
##           Estimate Std. Error
## Theta(1)   -0.4018      0.081
## BTheta(1)  -0.5569      0.078
## 
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.03672 on 128 degrees of freedom
## Log likelihood = 244.7, aic = 987.2 aicc = 987.4, bic(corrected for length) = -6.535

Several plot methods have been implemented and the focus was on using interactive tools. The default S3 generic plot() for example shows the time series with the dygraphs package (Vanderkam et al. 2018). The result is a zoomable line representation of the series, see Figure @ref(fig:plotmethod).

plot(obj_x13)

Output of the plot() method in the R-Studio viewer pane

Adjusting Parameters

All predefined JDemetra+ model specifications can be used in the calls to perX13 or perTramo (and also in the hierarchical functions), but most of the times it is still necessary to adjust parameters of seasonal adjustment steps more individually. This can of course be done. We will reuse the obj_x13 from before, which is generated with the RSA3 model specification.

The current parameters are stored in the field params.

obj_x13$params

They can be updated with updateParams(), e.g. to include some random outliers.

obj_x13$updateParams(usrdef.outliersEnabled = TRUE,
                     usrdef.outliersType = c("AO","LS","LS"),
                     usrdef.outliersDate=c("1950-01-01","1955-04-01","1959-10-01"))
obj_x13$run()

The output shows that the outliers are now included in the model.

obj_x13$output$regarima
## y = regression model + arima (0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1)
## Log-transformation: yes
## Coefficients:
##           Estimate Std. Error
## Theta(1)   -0.3914      0.082
## BTheta(1)  -0.5619      0.079
## 
##               Estimate Std. Error
## AO (1-1950)  -0.056775      0.029
## LS (4-1955)   0.023172      0.030
## LS (10-1959)  0.001298      0.031
## 
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.03607 on 125 degrees of freedom
## Log likelihood =   247, aic = 988.6 aicc = 989.3, bic(corrected for length) = -6.458

Persephone Hierarchical Objects

Hierarchical persephone objects are created with perHts(). There are two options on how to provide the ‘single’ objects as input. Firstly, directly as arguments, as shown below, this kind of call is mainly applicable for a quite limited number of time series.

obj_x13_1 <- perX13(AirPassengers, "RSA3")
obj_x13_2 <- perX13(AirPassengers, "RSA3")
obj_x13_hts <- perHts(ts1 = obj_x13_1, ts2 = obj_x13_2)

Secondly, several ‘single’ objects can be concatenated into a list and provided to the list argument of the perHts() function. We shall call these ‘single’ objects ‘components’ in this multivariate context.

In the more realistic examples below, we use time series of the volume index of production for total industry (except construction) of the EU-28 countries. They are monthly data published by Eurostat covering January 2000 through June 2019. Some series contain missing values. The data sets are downloaded from the Eurostat database (Eurostat 2019) and provided with the R package to be used in examples and tests. They can be simply loaded with the data function.

data(pi_caladj, pi_sa, pi_unadj, weights_pi_ea19, weights_pi_eu28)

We use the calendar and not seasonally adjusted data pi_caladj for illustrative purposes because they only contain one missing value. weights_pi_ea19 and weights_pi_eu28 are the data sets containing the weights per country.

We remove the EU-28 and EA-19 (Euro Area) aggregates.

pi_caladj_orig <- pi_caladj
pi_caladj <- pi_caladj[ , -c(1:2)]

We remove the last time point because of the missing value.

pi_caladj <- window(pi_caladj, end = c(2019, 5))

Aggregates without Weights

The next step is to construct a hierarchical persephone object that does not contain weights and computes aggregate series as the sum of the components.

To get started, we generate persephone objects with X13-ARIMA-SEATS as method for all countries’ time series. This is done by simply calling the R built-in function lapply to call the function perX13 on the multivariate time series object pi_caladj.

ts_28 <- lapply(pi_caladj, perX13)

The list argument in perHts() can be used to create a hierarchical persephone object based on a list of persephone single objects. Here we aggregate the Euro-area (EA-19) countries and set the method to be used for the direct adjustment of the aggregate series to x13 as well.

hts_EA19 <- perHts(list = ts_28[weights_pi_ea19$country], method = "x13")

We now generate our final hierarchical persephone object hts_EU28 which consists of the Euro-area countries as a hierarchical object and the 9 countries as single objects.

non_EA19 <- weights_pi_eu28$country[which(!weights_pi_eu28$country %in% weights_pi_ea19$country)]
hts_EU28 <- perHts(list = c(EA19=hts_EA19,ts_28[non_EA19]))

The structure of this object is represented in the print output. The “blank” component is the overall total.

hts_EU28
##  component run   class                 
##            FALSE hierarchicalTimeSeries
##  EA19      FALSE hierarchicalTimeSeries
##  EA19/BE   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/DE   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/EE   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/IE   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/EL   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/ES   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/FR   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/IT   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/CY   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/LT   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/LV   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/LU   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/MT   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/NL   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/AT   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/PT   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/SI   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/SK   FALSE x13Single             
##  EA19/FI   FALSE x13Single             
##  BG        FALSE x13Single             
##  CZ        FALSE x13Single             
##  DK        FALSE x13Single             
##  HR        FALSE x13Single             
##  HU        FALSE x13Single             
##  PL        FALSE x13Single             
##  RO        FALSE x13Single             
##  SE        FALSE x13Single             
##  UK        FALSE x13Single

We can initiate a first run with

hts_EU28$run()

and have a look at the summary (not yet implemented, but coming in an update of this vignette soon).

# summary(hts_EU28)

The only plot function implemented for hierarchical persephone objects at the moment is a general comparison line chart called through the S3 generic plot(), see Figure @ref(fig:plotmethodhts).

plot(hts_EU28)

Output of the plot() method for a hierarchical persephone object in the R-Studio viewer pane

We can however access the components of a hierarchical persephone object and use the methods developed for univariate analysis, e.g. we can plot the auto-correlations of the residuals for the Belgian time series, see Figure @ref(fig:acfresbg), where the component "BE" can either be addressed by hts_EU28$getComponent("EA19/BE") or by hts_EU28$components$EA19$components$BE.

plotResiduals(hts_EU28$getComponent("EA19/BE"), which = "acf", interactive = FALSE)

Output of the plotResiduals() method for the Belgian time series

Also the results of lower level aggregate series are accessed via the components. The EA19 aggregate for example would be plotted by using the following command:

plot(hts_EU28$getComponent("EA19"))

Weighted Aggregates

If the time series are indices, we are not really interested in the sum of the components but in the weighted sum. We can use either time-invariant or time-variant weights.

Time-invariant Weights

The weights parameter is set as a numeric vector with length equal to the number of components. The hierarchical persephone object is constructed in the same way as in the previous section but with weights, one for each component. Internally, an mts object is then created with constant weights for all time points.

We include the weights from the data set weights_pi_eu28 in the hierarchical persephone object:

# First we split the weights vector in two (EA19 and nonEA19)
w_EA19 <- weights_pi_eu28$weight[
   which(weights_pi_eu28$country %in% weights_pi_ea19$country)]
w_non_EA19 <- weights_pi_eu28$weight[
   which(!weights_pi_eu28$country %in% weights_pi_ea19$country)]
# The first perHts call is for the EA19 countries
hts_EA19 <- perHts(list = ts_28[weights_pi_ea19$country], method = "x13", weights = w_EA19)
# We then combine the hts_EA19 object with the non_EA19 countries.
hts_EU28 <- perHts(list = c(list(EA19 = hts_EA19),ts_28[non_EA19]), weights = w_non_EA19)

Please note that in the generation step of hts_EU28 the weights in w_non_EA19 are only used for the single persephone objects in the list input and not for the hierarchical persephone object hts_EA19.

To perform a run on all components, we just call the run method on the hts_EU28 object.

hts_EU28$run()

We can have a look at the weights of an object by accessing the weights field.

head(hts_EU28$weights)
##        EA19    BG    CZ    DK    HR    HU    PL    RO    SE     UK
## [1,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795
## [2,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795
## [3,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795
## [4,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795
## [5,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795
## [6,] 73.751 0.394 1.977 1.879 0.324 1.126 3.835 0.993 2.926 12.795

We can also show that the EU-28 aggregate series generated by persephone matches the data published by Eurostat apart from certain rounding differences:

# Eurostat EU28-Series
window(pi_caladj_orig[, "EU28"], start = c(2019,1))
##        Jan   Feb   Mar   Apr   May   Jun
## 2019 103.4 103.4 114.1 104.6 106.7 106.8
# Persephone EU28-Series
window(hts_EU28$ts, start = c(2019,1))
##           Jan      Feb      Mar      Apr      May
## 2019 103.3384 103.3205 113.9927 104.4974 106.5973
# Maximum absolute difference
max(abs(pi_caladj_orig[, "EU28"] - hts_EU28$ts))
## [1] 0.112941

Time-variant Weights

We do not have a real-life example for time-variant weights which is why we generate artificial weights for our example.

This R code can be ignored as it is used to make the weights randomly time-variant. The result is a list of time series, one for each country.

weights_pi_eu28_time <- do.call("c", apply(weights_pi_eu28,1, function(x){
   l <-  list(ts(rlnorm(nrow(pi_caladj))/5 + as.numeric(x[2]),start = start(pi_caladj),
                 end = end(pi_caladj),
                 frequency = frequency(pi_caladj)))
   names(l) <- x[1]
   return(l)
   }))

We can then create a hierarchical persephone object as in the previous section

w_EA19 <- weights_pi_eu28_time[which(weights_pi_eu28$country %in% weights_pi_ea19$country)]
w_non_EA19 <- weights_pi_eu28_time[which(!weights_pi_eu28$country %in% weights_pi_ea19$country)]

hts_EA19 <- perHts(list = ts_28[weights_pi_ea19$country], method = "x13", weights=w_EA19)
hts_EU28 <- perHts(list = c(list(EA19 = hts_EA19),ts_28[non_EA19]), weights = w_non_EA19)

and perform a run.

hts_EU28$run()

Eurostat Quality Report

The function generateQrTable() renders a Eurostat quality report (QR) in the form of a data.frame which can then be exported by the user.

eurostatQR <- generateQrTable(hts_EU28)
head(eurostatQR)
##   component Method Period Nobs  Start    End Log.Transformation    ARIMA.Model
## 1               TS     12  233 1-2000 5-2019               TRUE (1 1 0)(0 1 1)
## 2      EA19    x13     12  233 1-2000 5-2019              FALSE (0 1 1)(0 1 1)
## 3   EA19/BE    x13     12  233 1-2000 5-2019              FALSE (0 1 1)(0 1 1)
## 4   EA19/DE    x13     12  233 1-2000 5-2019              FALSE (1 1 2)(0 1 1)
## 5   EA19/EE    x13     12  233 1-2000 5-2019               TRUE (3 1 1)(0 1 1)
## 6   EA19/IE    x13     12  233 1-2000 5-2019               TRUE (1 1 1)(0 1 1)
##   LeapYear MovingHoliday NbTD Noutliers     Outlier1     Outlier2    Outlier3
## 1    FALSE         FALSE    6         2 LS (11-2008)  LS (1-2009)        <NA>
## 2     TRUE         FALSE    7         2 LS (11-2008) TC (11-2008)        <NA>
## 3     TRUE         FALSE    7         2 LS (11-2008)  AO (5-2009)        <NA>
## 4     TRUE         FALSE    7         3  LS (1-2009) LS (11-2008) TC (3-2009)
## 5    FALSE         FALSE    0         2 LS (10-2008) TC (10-2008)        <NA>
## 6    FALSE          TRUE    0         4  LS (2-2015)  LS (2-2014) AO (3-2018)
##   CombinedTest_SI Residual.Seasonality Residual.TD.Effect Q.Stat
## 1         Present                   No                 No     NA
## 2         Present                   No                 No   0.19
## 3         Present                   No                 No   0.35
## 4         Present                   No                 No   0.23
## 5         Present                   No                Yes   0.26
## 6            None                   No                 No   1.76
##   Final.Henderson.Filter Stage.2.Henderson.Filter Seasonal.Filter Max.Adj
## 1                   <NA>                     <NA>            <NA>     21%
## 2                    H13                      H13             3x5     27%
## 3                    H13                      H13             3x5     14%
## 4                    H13                      H13             3x5      9%
## 5                    H13                      H13             3x5     12%
## 6                    H23                      H23             3x5     23%

The Eurostat QR corresponds to the JD+ plugin version 1 (Ladiray 2018), with the exception that no overall index of quality is included since it is not available to us from RJDemetra at the moment and is not trivial to recalculate.

Future Enhancements

The package is still under heavy development, some of the features we want to include in the future are:

  • Diagnostics for hierarchical time series
  • Benchmark method for direct adjustments
  • Pure batch objects
  • Summary method
  • Dashboard for large numbers of time series

Bureau, US Census. 2019. “X-13 ARIMA SEATS Seasonal Adjustment Program.” https://www.census.gov/srd/www/x13as/.

Kowarik, Alexander, Angelika Meraner, Matthias Templ, and Daniel Schopfhauser. 2014. “Seasonal Adjustment with the R Packages x12 and x12GUI.” Journal of Statistical Software 62 (2): 1–21. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v62/i02/.
Ladiray, Dominique. 2018. “JD+ Quality Report for Eurostat Job Vacancy Survey.” https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/cros/content/61-insee-plugin-eurostat-job-vacancy-survey_en.

Qiu, Yixuan. 2019. Prettydoc: Creating Pretty Documents from r Markdown. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=prettydoc.
Quartier-la-Tente, Alain, Anna Michalek, Jean Palate, and Raf Baeyens. 2019. RJDemetra: Interface to ’JDemetra+’ Seasonal Adjustment Software. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=RJDemetra.
